content: Haidee i'm scottie here welcome back to the DMS craft today I was going to talk
about some of the large figures that you can the pre painted figures you can buy
there they're a nice time saver you can get a lot of them pretty cheaply on eBay
and various hobby stores and things are tons of websites but there is one

show you how to fix that today and we'll get right to it on the DMS correct
so here's a figure I want to talk about I've got a really cool giant croc on a
large bass because it's a it's a large very large creature and see you got a
really cool looking model on a plain black bass and that just really detracts
I think from the model itself and makes it look very gamy in my era gameboard
Ian might be like peace in my opinion so what can we do to fix that there's a
very easy solution I'm going to show you right now
now in this case I want the face to look muddy and swampy so what I'm going to do
is I'm going to use the same modeling paste that I used on the wagon to give
it the texture and we're going to apply this paste to the base and you won't
believe the transformation of the manager
I've got it really tight in here so you can see what I'm doing on the base so
what I'm going to do is grab a glob of the modeling paste and I got it right
there and I'll apply it to the base and you don't want it to be too smooth you
want to have texture you don't want to have the stuff tends to want to leave
points and you want to kind of mush those down squish them so you want to
really make it look like a muddy mess that this croc is rampaging around in
so the trick is to kind of you know get between the toes and everything you want
to cover all the base now you don't really need to worry about getting it on
the model you can just paint that it'll just look like some mud guy which
actually adds to the effect so just want to make sure you get between those toes
around the feet so you can like pull your brush through
the stuff just make it look globby and there you
go that's kind of what the effect you're going to get now I'm going to finish the
base and then I'll show you that and we'll move on to the next step
here we go I've got the croc base all painted or all at the texture all
applied so I'll kind of spin it around so you can see so that definitely has a
rough texture on it on that base there and you want to make sure you keep it
off the edges if it comes off the edge just kind of get it off with your finger
you want to keep the edge clear I have my base all dried so I'm all
ready to move to the next step I am going to use a burnt umber and paint the
base so I get some and just look generously don't worry about getting
some on the model that's okay if the paint's a little thick feel free
to use some water okay now I've got all the but on their
painted I'll see how much better that looks than just that black base kind of
nice so now um what I'm going to do is I'm going to add some of that burnt
bumper to the model itself so I'm going to wet it down quite a bit it's called a
wash I'm just gonna start painting it on and if you think it's coming on too
thick you can always send it off with some water once I look like this crock
just really pop down the mud now let's just add an extra degree of
shading to the model these models tend to be bare minimum as far as painting
goes and if you I put some on the teeth too and if you feel like you have too
much on the teeth you know I just use your finger and wipe some off
okay so I'll give you a little closer shot there you can see how that's
already added some nice shading to the model it's wet right now so it's looking
extra glossy but when that dries out it'll it'll flatten down so there we go
we'll let this dry and that will move on to the next step
you know what I'm going to do is do a little bit of dry crushing I've got a
light brown so I'll do that first then kind of kind of go over the mud areas to
give it some dimension it'll add some dimension because the mud is let's down
with the darker color so I'm using a lighter brown want to make sure you get
up under the model also going to do a little bit on the crocodile itself
got that now what I'm going to do is use some
green this is an olive green I'm just going to hit them on a little bit less
than the I did with the light brown and you don't have to wait for the light
brown to totally dry somebody somewhere that's green on the
croc this croc has some branches or has some plants on his top like it was under
the mud something like that does a little more with the green but on the
croc itself usage that kind of make this scales pop
out just very lightly and there we go now we've improved our
dull-looking model added to it now the one nice thing about the acrylic paint
is since it's the acrylic itself is kind of a stretchy paint so these models have
some bend to them they're not hard plastic they're kind of a medium
hardness plastic so the paint will stretch with it so you don't worry about
the paint coming off and there we go one way you can improve your models of the
giant hideous black bases and see you next time on the DMS craft
